ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a great overview of American Indian law and policies surrounding them. I also feel like this class was a great precursor to law school.

I gained an insight into the robust world of federal Indian law and policy, a world largely unknown to majority of scholars. We approached all scholarly work with a historical lens which allowed us to interrogate more history, law, and other academic fields.
I learned so so much about federal Indian law, the history and present impact of policies.
Understanding of American Indian policy from the Marshall trilogy cases to the present day with issues like gaming and child welfare

This was my first academic experience with government legislation. The class greatly expanded my idea of sovereignty and how legislation connects to policy. There was a focus on the growth of tribal powers over time, as well as the current and ongoing issues between tribes and the federal government. There was also a (much appreciated) focus on the difference between undergraduate study and law school study over legislation. The class revealed to me how many ways law and policy can be analyzed and interpreted. It also gave me enough practice with law to feel comfortable taking another class on government with less initial hand-holding.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved this class!

Strengths - It seems many more Indian law cases enter the legal radar as the US reckons with legal and racial history. Therefore, the instructor has the ability to incorporate different legal cases and legislative procedures into course materials. 

Weakness - The instructors does not understand how to fully operate all the necessary technologies to ensure a good virtual classroom.
This class teaches so much about a specific part of Native American history that is fascinating and seldom taught in any other class

Weakness of the class: the instructor grades too harshly off the bat without adequately preparing students with information about his standards. The course's reading load is also poorly distributed--there's a lot more reading in the beginning and very little in the end. Strengths: the course material is fascinating, the assignments are well-designed and interesting to complete, and the instructor is really invested in student learning.

I really learned a lot in this class, and I think everyone should learn more about American Indian history. The assignments were not too demanding, and Professor Blackhawk was very accommodating. I do think it might have been better off as a longer seminar once a week than meeting for a shorter time twice a week, because it sometimes felt like we didn't get to have a full conversation about the readings, but other than that, I can't think of any weaknesses!

Strengths: Engaging readings. Grading that dramatically improves writing style. Engaging discussions in class. Incredible guest speakers. Class does not feel hard to keep up with. Good for people with an interest in Indian Law and structure of American government. Relevant to modern issues.

Weaknesses: Some readings came directly from law journals, so their length and verbage were hard to engage with. Some readings were too long, so seminar discussions rarely incorporated close analysis of texts. Class discussions often deviated from plans on syllabus, so it was hard to remain motivated to do all of the readings. Grammar and sentence structure are really addressed in the class, so it feels like it impacts one's essay grade to an extent larger than feels necessary.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Blackhawk incorporated his partner, a law instructor from UPenn, to co-facilitate sessions of our classrooms. This allowed undergraduates students to engage with a law class which was quite the experience.
This class didn't have breaks or a change in engagement during long Zoom calls, it didn't translate very well online (I've taken other classes with this professor)

Keeping seminars small was a good move. Sharing presentations was also manageable. Easy access to texts was also helpful. This was a morning class, so it was the only class I was somewhat happy went virtual since I could just slide out of bed. Professor prefers to grade by hand, so receiving feedback on papers was limited.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! If you want to go to law school, take it. If you want to go into government, take it. If you want to be a knowledgeable, well-rounded person, take it. I feel like everyone would benefit from this class!
No, Professor Blackhawk's approach to his students remains out-of-touch which does not foster an engage environment for course work.

This class is great if you have any interest in Native American history or law, as someone who wants to go into federal law, it was an incredibly important basis, and I actually got to learn more in the field of Natives studies which I haven't done for years, so it was intellectually challenging and great

Yes, I think it's important to learn about American Indian history because this is often left out of American history education. I also think this is a great opportunity for people interested in law because it exposes you to reading cases and law review articles, and Professor Blackhawk brings in guests who talk about law school and careers in federal Indian law. And Professor Blackhawk is great!
I would recommend this course if you are motivated to take the course. It is good for students wanting to attend law school, but there is some downtime for students who do not.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar, but kind of leminar because the professor mostly led discussion
N/A
